10.summary: According to Tafsir al-Mizan, this verse identify the dukhan as a definitive sign preceding the Day of Judgment, symbolizing cosmic upheaval and the unraveling of the natural order as part of qiyamah’s portents. In Surah Ad-Dukhaan, verse 10, Allah commands believers to anticipate a profound moment: "Then watch for the Day when the sky will bring a visible smoke" (فَٱرْتَقِبْ يَوْمَ تَأْتِى ٱلسَّمَآءُ بِدُخَانٍۢ مُّبِينٍۢ). The term *dukhan* (دُخَانٍۢ) refers to a dense, unmistakable smoke enveloping the sky, while *mubeen* (مُّبِينٍۢ) emphasises its clarity and undeniable nature. Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain this as both a historical warning and an eschatological sign. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) taught that this "visible smoke" manifests on two levels: a physical sign preceding the Final Hour and a spiritual metaphor for the fog of misguidance that engulfs hearts when truth is rejected. This verse invites reflection on how "smoke" manifests metaphorically—confusion, corruption, or crises clouding moral clarity.
10.layer2short: In Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:10, the divine command *"Then watch for the Day when the sky will bring a visible smoke"* has been interpreted by classical Shia exegetes through both literal and symbolic lenses, rooted in the theological framework of the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings. Sheikh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, outlines two primary perspectives: one historical and one eschatological. Historically, this "smoke" (dukhan) is linked to a severe famine in Mecca during the Prophet’s time, understood as a divine punishment for the Quraysh’s rejection of revelation. This event, marked by visible atmospheric disturbance, served as a tangible warning of God’s power, compelling repentance. Eschatologically, Tabrisi and later scholars like Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* identify the dukhan as a definitive sign preceding the Day of Judgment, symbolizing cosmic upheaval and the unraveling of the natural order as part of qiyamah’s portents.
10.layer2short_urdu: سورہ اڈ-ڈوخان 44:10 میں ، الہی کمانڈ * "پھر اس دن کے لئے دیکھیں جب آسمان ایک دھواں دلائے گا" * * کلاسیکی شیعہ کے ذریعہ لفظی اور علامتی لینسوں کے ذریعہ تشریح کی گئی ہے ، جو اہل بائٹ کی تعلیمات کے مذہبی فریم ورک میں ہے۔ شیخ تبریسی ، *ماجما البیان *میں ، دو بنیادی نقطہ نظر کا خاکہ پیش کرتے ہیں: ایک تاریخی اور ایک اسکیٹولوجیکل۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ "دھواں" (دوکھن) نبی of کے زمانے میں مکہ میں ایک سخت قحط سے منسلک ہے ، جسے قریش کے انکشاف کے مسترد ہونے کی خدائی سزا کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ یہ واقعہ ، جس میں دکھائے جانے والے ماحولیاتی خلل کی وجہ سے نشان زد کیا گیا ہے ، خدا کی قدرت کی ایک ٹھوس انتباہ کے طور پر کام کیا ، توبہ کو مجبور کیا۔ اسکاٹولوجیکل طور پر ، تبریسی اور بعد کے اسکالرز جیسے * المزان * میں علامہ تبتابائی جیسے ڈوکھن کو فیصلے کے دن سے پہلے ایک حتمی علامت کے طور پر شناخت کرتے ہیں ، جس میں کائناتی اتار چڑھاؤ اور قیعیمہ کے پورٹینٹس کے حصے کے طور پر قدرتی نظم و ضبط کی علامت ہے۔

11.layer1:
The verse *yaghsha al-nasa hadha adhabun alim* (Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:11) describes a divine punishment that envelops humanity like a suffocating cloud. The word *yaghsha* (يَغْشَى) derives from *ghashiya*, meaning to cover or overwhelm completely, suggesting a sudden, inescapable calamity. The *adhab alim* (عَذَابٌ أَلِيمٌ) refers not merely to physical pain but to a profound spiritual and existential anguish. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, interprets this "smoke" (*dukhaan*) as both a historical warning and an eschatological sign. Historically, it is linked to a severe famine in Mecca during the Prophet’s (s) time, when disbelievers faced drought and starvation as a consequence of rejecting his message. Eschatologically, it points to the tribulations preceding the Day of Judgment, symbolizing the chaos and moral obscurity that will test humanity’s faith.

The verse underscores Allah’s mercy even in punishment: the Meccan famine temporarily eased when some Quraysh leaders begged for relief, demonstrating that repentance can avert disaster. Key terms like *alim* (painful) emphasize the holistic nature of divine justice—punishment is proportionate to the arrogance and heedlessness of those who deny truth. For contemporary Muslims, this verse serves as a metaphor for the spiritual "smoke" of materialism, injustice, and moral confusion that clouds modern life. Just as the early Muslims were urged to seek refuge in faith and community during crises, today’s believers are reminded to anchor themselves in Quranic guidance and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as), who illuminate the path through darkness. Practically, this calls for self-accountability, resisting societal corruption, and fostering collective resilience—recognizing that divine justice ultimately prevails, and clarity emerges for those who strive for *taqwa* (God-consciousness)
11.layer2:
In interpreting Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:11, classical Shia exegetes emphasize both the literal and metaphysical dimensions of the "covering" (yaghsha) described. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, identifies this phenomenon as a dense smoke or mist (dukhan) enveloping humanity as a prelude to divine punishment, drawing parallels to historical calamities such as the famine endured by the Quraysh during their persecution of the Prophet (PBUH). This tangible manifestation serves as both a warning and a manifestation of Allah’s justice (ʿadl), underscoring the inevitability of accountability for oppression.  

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands this into a metaphysical framework, interpreting the "covering" as symbolic of spiritual blindness—a consequence of persistent disbelief and moral corruption. The "painful torment" (ʿadhab alim) thus operates on dual planes: immediate physical suffering and the enduring agony of severed connection with the Divine. Shia theology uniquely links such trials to the cosmic role of the Ahlul Bayt (AS), who serve as guides through temporal and spiritual tribulations. The verse is seen as an allusion to the necessity of Imamah, wherein the Imam’s presence lifts the "covering" of ignorance, while his occultation signifies a period of collective trial.  

Scholars like Sheikh al-Tusi in *Al-Tibyan* contextualize this within eschatology, aligning the smoke with signs of the Hour and the Mahdi’s eventual reappearance to eradicate oppression. The verse thus bridges individual moral responsibility and collective divine justice, reinforcing Shia doctrines of resurrection (maʿad) and intercession (shafaʿa). Jurisprudentially, it underscores the obligation to seek guidance from the Infallibles (AS) to navigate both worldly trials and spiritual peril, affirming the Shia paradigm of reason (ʿaql) illuminated by prophetic and imamic wisdom.
11.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars interpret Surah Dukhan 44:11’s depiction of a “covering torment” through multilayered lenses, blending eschatological warnings with urgent modern realities. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, notes that while classical commentaries describe this “smoke” (dukhan) as a literal sign of divine punishment preceding Judgment Day, its symbolic resonance extends to humanity’s self-inflicted crises. He parallels the verse’s imagery to environmental collapse, citing air pollution as a tangible “covering” of toxic smog—a man-made “torment” choking cities from Tehran to Beijing, reflecting humanity’s disconnect from Quranic stewardship (khalifa) of Earth.  

This interpretation aligns with ecological theology frameworks discussed by scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, who links environmental degradation to spiritual bankruptcy, urging Muslims to address climate change as a moral imperative. Philosophically, the “painful torment” echoes modern existential crises—alienation, inequality, and war—which scholar Sayyed Ammar Nakshawani contextualizes as symptoms of systemic injustice condemned by the Ahlul Bayt. The verse’s universality invites interfaith dialogue; Rabbi Yonatan Neril’s interreligious environmental initiatives mirror Islamic calls for collective responsibility.  

Socially, the pandemic’s global “covering” of suffering—both viral and socio-economic—serves as a visceral modern analogy. The verse challenges us to recognize how structural greed and negligence perpetuate cycles of harm, urging transformative empathy. In a multicultural world, this verse becomes a bridge between faith and science, tradition and progress—a divine reminder that torment, whether spiritual or ecological, demands proactive redemption through ethical awakening.
11.layer4:
In the luminous teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), the "painful torment" described in Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:11) transcends mere physical suffering. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Burhan* that this "covering smoke" symbolizes the spiritual blindness and suffocation that envelops hearts detached from the light of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). The true torment lies not in worldly afflictions but in the soul's estrangement from its divine purpose and the guidance of the Imams.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) declared, *"The greatest torment is the separation from the Imam of one’s time."* This verse, therefore, warns against the spiritual death that comes from rejecting the *Imamah*—the lifeline connecting humanity to Allah’s mercy. The smoke represents the confusion, doubt, and misguidance that arise when hearts turn away from the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, *"The fire of hell is but a veil over a greater fire: the fire of hearts burning with regret over lost opportunities to know their Lord."*

Practically, this verse calls believers to anchor themselves in the love and obedience of the Imams. Daily *ziyarat*, sincere supplications like *Dua al-Ahd*, and reflecting on the tragedies of Karbala purify the heart from the "smoke" of negligence. Imam al-Baqir (peace be upon him) advised, *"Recite Surah Ad-Dukhaan with the awareness that its cure is found in clinging to our Wilayah."* By nurturing loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt and embodying their ethics—justice, patience, and truthfulness—believers dispel the darkness of spiritual heedlessness and walk in the radiant light of divine guidance.

* التیبیان * میں شیخ التوسی جیسے اسکالرز اس کو ایسکیٹولوجی کے اندر سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں ، اور اس وقت کی علامتوں کے ساتھ دھوئیں کو سیدھ میں کرتے ہیں اور جبر کے خاتمے کے لئے مہدی کی حتمی طور پر ظاہر ہوتی ہے۔ اس طرح یہ آیت انفرادی اخلاقی ذمہ داری اور اجتماعی الہی انصاف کو ختم کرتی ہے ، جس سے قیامت کے شیعہ عقائد (ما aاد) اور شفاعت (شافا) کو تقویت ملتی ہے۔ فقہی طور پر ، یہ انفلیئبلز (جیسے) سے دنیاوی آزمائشوں اور روحانی خطرہ دونوں پر تشریف لے جانے کے لئے رہنمائی حاصل کرنے کی ذمہ داری کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جس نے پیشن گوئی اور امامک حکمت سے روشن ہونے والی شیعہ مثال (ااکل) کی تصدیق کی ہے۔

11.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:11, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on its core eschatological meaning, identifying the "covering torment" as a divine punishment manifesting as smoke (dukhan) preceding the Day of Judgment. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) both cite prophetic traditions describing this phenomenon as a literal, universal calamity, underscoring shared eschatological beliefs. Al-Qurtubi and Al-Tabrisi similarly emphasise the verse’s warning function, urging spiritual vigilance. This consensus reflects a unified theological foundation in affirming God’s power to enact justice and the inevitability of accountability.

Divergences emerge in contextualising the verse’s temporal application. Sunni scholars like Ibn Kathir and Al-Razi often link the "smoke" to historical events, such as a drought during the Meccan siege, interpreting it as both a past warning and a future sign. In contrast, Shia commentators like Al-Qummi and Tabatabai, while acknowledging eschatological dimensions, also read the verse as allegorically referencing the suffering of the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Mizan posits that the "painful torment" symbolises the moral and spiritual decay faced by those opposing divine guidance, with the smoke metaphorically obscuring truth. This reflects the Shia emphasis on the Imamah’s role in preserving spiritual clarity amidst societal corruption.

These differences stem from distinct hermeneutical priorities: Sunni tafsir often prioritises historical literalism and prophetic precedent, whereas Shia exegesis integrates metaphysical symbolism tied to the Imams’ legacy. While both traditions inspire piety and ethical consciousness, Sunni interpretations may emphasise individual preparedness for the hereafter, while Shia readings reinforce communal allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt as a means of navigating spiritual trials. Such variations illustrate how theological frameworks shape textual engagement, rooted in historical experiences of authority and interpretation.

The verse *yaghsha al-nasa hadha adhabun alim* (Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:11) describes a divine punishment that envelops humanity like a suffocating cloud. The word *yaghsha* (يَغْشَى) derives from *ghashiya*, meaning to cover or overwhelm completely, suggesting a sudden, inescapable calamity. The *adhab alim* (عَذَابٌ أَلِيمٌ) refers not merely to physical pain but to a profound spiritual and existential anguish. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Burhan* that this "covering smoke" symbolizes the spiritual blindness and suffocation that envelops hearts detached from the light of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Just as the early Muslims were urged to seek refuge in faith and community during crises, today’s believers are reminded to anchor themselves in Quranic guidance and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as), who illuminate the path through darkness.

12.layer1:
This verse from Surah Ad-Dukhaan captures a moment of desperate pleading from people facing divine punishment, crying out: *"Rabbana kshif anna al-adhab, inna mu'minun"* (Our Lord, remove this torment from us; we are true believers now). Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that this plea reflects a recurring human tendency to claim faith only when confronted with consequences, rather than cultivating sincere belief beforehand. The verse is understood to address the disbelievers of Prophet Muhammad’s (SAW) time, who mocked his warnings until facing hardship, like the famine mentioned in historical accounts of Mecca. The term *"adhab"* (torment) here refers not only to physical suffering but to the spiritual consequences of rejecting truth, while *"kshif"* (remove) implies lifting a veil of heedlessness – suggesting punishment serves as both consequence and awakening.  

Shia narrations, including traditions from Imam Ali (AS), emphasize that true faith requires consistency, not transactional declarations in moments of crisis. The verse’s context – revealed during Meccan persecution – parallels modern challenges where individuals neglect spiritual priorities until struck by personal or societal crises. Today, this serves as a reminder to nurture genuine *iman* (faith) through daily practice, repentance, and trust in Allah’s wisdom, rather than treating faith as an emergency appeal. It also invites reflection on societal injustices: just as the verse critiques hollow claims of belief, Muslims are urged to align their actions with Islamic principles proactively, addressing oppression and moral decay before they escalate into collective suffering. The cry *"inna mu'minun"* (we are believers) becomes a caution against self-deception, urging believers to internalize faith as a lived reality, not a last-minute bargaining chip.
12.layer2:
In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:12), the plea *"Our Lord, remove from us the torment; indeed, we are believers"* is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as a desperate supplication by those facing divine punishment after persistent rejection of truth. This verse encapsulates themes of divine justice, the conditional nature of faith, and the futility of late repentance when confronted with irreversible consequences. As expounded in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, the verse refers to disbelievers—often identified as Pharaoh’s people or the Quraysh—who, upon experiencing calamity, superficially profess faith to evade punishment. Their declaration *"indeed, we are believers"* is deemed insincere, reflecting transactional faith born of desperation rather than genuine conviction. 

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* underscores the theological principle that true belief (iman) necessitates both inward conviction and outward submission to divine guidance, including recognition of wilayah (divinely ordained authority). The verse thus critiques hollow claims of faith divorced from righteous action and allegiance to truth. Shia exegesis frequently links such passages to the broader doctrine of *tawbah* (repentance), emphasizing that sincere repentance must precede the onset of divine punishment (*‘idhab*), as later remorse holds no merit. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, clarifies that Allah’s mercy responds to preemptive spiritual awakening, not opportunistic pleas under duress. 

This verse also resonates with Shia juridical concepts of moral accountability, where faith is inseparable from adherence to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. The disbelievers’ belated appeal—devoid of transformative commitment—highlights the inviolability of divine justice, wherein mercy is granted through sustained righteousness, not momentary desperation. Thus, the verse serves as a caution against deferring spiritual reform, affirming that authentic faith manifests in lifelong devotion, not circumstantial declarations.
12.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Dukhan 44:12 is often interpreted as a cautionary reflection on the human tendency toward transactional spirituality—seeking divine intervention in moments of crisis without sustained commitment to ethical transformation. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that the verse exposes the insincerity of Pharaoh’s people, who professed belief only *after* facing calamity, highlighting Islam’s rejection of performative faith divorced from moral action. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to today’s "crisis spirituality," where individuals or societies appeal to higher powers during pandemics or climate disasters but revert to complacency once immediate threats subside.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with discussions on anthropogenic climate crises: humanity’s plea to "remove the torment" of extreme weather parallels our delayed reckoning with environmental destruction. Philosopher Dr. Fatimah Tabatabai notes that the verse critiques a mechanistic view of prayer—treating God as a "fixer" rather than engaging in the self-reflection and systemic change required to address root causes. Socially, this mirrors movements for racial and economic justice, where superficial reforms often replace transformative accountability.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Jewish and Christian scholars, draw parallels between this Quranic warning and concepts like *teshuvah* (repentance) or "cheap grace," underscoring a shared ethical imperative: authentic belief necessitates sustained justice. In our interconnected world, the verse challenges communities to move beyond crisis-driven appeals toward holistic, proactive faith—a lesson urgently needed amid global inequities and ecological brinkmanship.
12.layer4:
The plea of "Our Lord, remove from us the torment; indeed, we are believers" (44:12) is a profound lesson in sincerity and the essence of true faith. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this verse exposes the weakness of claiming belief *after* facing consequences, rather than nurturing unwavering conviction through righteous action and submission to divine guardianship (*Wilayah*). Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "Faith is not by hope, but by what resides in hearts and is proven by deeds" (*Nahj al-Balagha*). The verse’s callers, though uttering words of belief, lacked the spiritual substance of *Tawhid* and loyalty to the divine covenant embodied in the Imamah.  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains that true faith necessitates recognizing the Imam of one’s time as the gateway to Allah’s mercy: "Whoever dies without knowing the Imam of his time dies the death of ignorance" (*Al-Kafi*). The torment mentioned here is not merely physical; it symbolizes the spiritual void of estrangement from the guiding light of the Ahlul Bayt. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that salvation lies in anchoring one’s heart to the "rope of Allah" (3:103) – the unbreakable bond of love and obedience to the purified Household.  

Practically, this verse urges believers to preemptively seek protection through sincere repentance (*tawbah*), daily adherence to the Imams’ teachings, and embodying *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) amidst trials. The supplication taught by Imam Zain al-Abidin (peace be upon him) in *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya* encapsulates this: "O Allah, make me fear You as if I see You, and grant me happiness through reverence for You, not through the hardship of Your punishment." Let our faith be a living covenant with the *Wilayah* of the Ahlul Bayt, not a desperate cry when calamity strikes.

12.layer5:
In interpreting Q44:12, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core narrative: disbelievers facing divine punishment plead for relief, professing faith belatedly. Classical Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir contextualise this within the Meccan polytheists’ rejection of Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), noting their insincere repentance upon witnessing eschatological torment (Ibn Kathir). Similarly, Shia sources such as Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* identify the supplicants as Pharaoh’s people or the Quraysh, stressing their recognition of truth only after divine chastisement (Tabrisi). Both traditions agree this reflects a Quranic principle: faith under duress holds no merit, as emphasised in Q40:85.

Divergences emerge in theological implications. Sunni scholars like Qurtubi and Razi focus on divine justice and human accountability, framing the verse as a warning against delaying repentance until death (Qurtubi). Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* underscores Allah’s transcendence, arguing the disbelievers’ plea reveals their flawed understanding of divine mercy contingent on preemptive faith. Shia commentaries, while affirming divine justice, integrate the concept of *walaya* (allegiance to Ahl al-Bayt). Al-Qummi’s tafsir links sincere belief to recognising the Imams’ guardianship, suggesting superficial faith without this recognition remains invalid. Tusi’s *Al-Tibyan* similarly posits that true belief necessitates adherence to divine guidance through the Prophet’s progeny.

These differences reflect distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis prioritises God’s attributes and human responsibility, while Shia readings emphasise the necessity of divinely appointed leadership for valid faith. Historically, Shia interpretations arose in contexts where political and spiritual authority were intertwined with the Imamate, whereas Sunni scholarship developed within broader communal consensus. Both traditions, however, utilise this verse to reinforce core ethical principles: sincerity in belief, the urgency of repentance, and the consequences of rejecting truth. Such nuanced differences enrich Islamic intellectual heritage without negating shared moral imperatives.

12.summary: In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:12), the plea *"Our Lord, remove from us the torment; indeed, we are believers"* is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as a desperate supplication by those facing divine punishment after persistent rejection of truth. This verse from Surah Ad-Dukhaan captures a moment of desperate pleading from people facing divine punishment, crying out: *"Rabbana kshif anna al-adhab, inna mu'minun"* (Our Lord, remove this torment from us; we are true believers now). Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that this plea reflects a recurring human tendency to claim faith only when confronted with consequences, rather than cultivating sincere belief beforehand. The verse is understood to address the disbelievers of Prophet Muhammad’s (SAW) time, who mocked his warnings until facing hardship, like the famine mentioned in historical accounts of Mecca. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "Faith is not by hope, but by what resides in hearts and is proven by deeds" (*Nahj al-Balagha*). The cry *"inna mu'minun"* (we are believers) becomes a caution against self-deception, urging believers to internalize faith as a lived reality, not a last-minute bargaining chip.

As expounded in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, the verse refers to disbelievers—often identified as Pharaoh’s people or the Quraysh—who, upon experiencing calamity, superficially profess faith to evade punishment. Their declaration *"indeed, we are believers"* is deemed insincere, reflecting transactional faith born of desperation rather than genuine conviction.

13.layer1:
In Surah Ad-Dukhaan verse 13, Allah poses a profound rhetorical question: "How will there be for them a reminder [at that time]? And there had come to them a clear Messenger." This verse addresses the disbelievers of Mecca who rejected Prophet Muhammad (SAW) despite his clear message. The term *adh-dhikra* (the reminder) refers to both the Quran’s guidance and the opportunity to repent, while *rasoolun mubeen* (clear Messenger) underscores the Prophet’s role as an unambiguous bearer of truth. The verse’s tone is one of divine rebuke, questioning how these people could expect further chances for guidance after having already dismissed the ultimate source of it—the Prophet himself—who manifested truth through his character, miracles, and the Quran’s clarity.

Historically, this verse reflects the Quraysh’s stubbornness during the Meccan period, when they demanded supernatural signs while ignoring the Prophet’s transformative message. Classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* emphasise that rejecting a "clear Messenger" after receiving his message leaves no valid excuse for disbelief. The word *mubeen* (clear) signifies that the Prophet’s mission was evident in both word and action, leaving no ambiguity for sincere seekers. Some Shia interpretations also extend the concept of "reminder" to include the ongoing guidance of the Ahlul Bayt (AS), who preserved and explained the Prophet’s teachings after him.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse serves as a warning against spiritual complacency. Just as the Quraysh dismissed the Prophet despite his clarity, many today overlook Islam’s teachings while seeking superficial "signs" or distractions. The verse calls us to value the guidance we already have—the Quran, the Prophet’s Sunnah, and the wisdom of the Imams—rather than delaying repentance or demanding new proofs. It reminds us that true guidance is often rejected not due to obscurity, but due to arrogance or attachment to worldly desires. By internalising the "reminder" through daily reflection on divine teachings and embodying the Messenger’s clarity in our conduct, we avoid the heedlessness condemned in this verse.
13.layer2:
In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:13), the verse poses a profound rhetorical question: "How will there be for them a reminder [at that time]? And there had come to them a clear Messenger." Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, emphasize the theological implications of rejecting divine guidance after the advent of an unequivocal Messenger. The verse underscores the inexcusability of disbelief once truth has been manifestly delivered, a theme recurrent in Shia theology concerning the necessity of recognizing both prophetic and Imamic authority.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, interprets the "reminder" (dhikra) as referring to the Quran and the enduring warnings of divine accountability. He notes that the verse critiques the disbelievers’ demand for renewed signs despite the Prophet Muhammad’s explicit message, highlighting their willful obstinacy. The "clear Messenger" (rasulun mubin) is understood not merely as the Prophet himself but also as the embodiment of his message—a theme Shia scholars extend to the Imams from his progeny, who perpetuate this clarity of guidance. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *Imamah*, wherein the Imams are the preserved inheritors of prophetic knowledge, ensuring the continuity of divine remembrance.

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands on the ontological relationship between the Messenger and the message. He argues that the Prophet’s presence itself constitutes an ultimate "reminder," rendering subsequent calls for proof illogical. The verse thus becomes a condemnation of those who, despite witnessing the Prophet’s miracles and moral perfection, persist in denial—a stance mirroring Shia critiques of those who rejected the rightful leadership of Imam Ali after the Prophet’s death. Theologically, this reflects the principle of *lutf* (divine grace), whereby God provides unambiguous guidance to remove human excuses for disbelief.

Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the obligation to heed divinely appointed authorities, a cornerstone of Shia legal theory. The failure to recognize the "clear Messenger" transcends mere historical rebuke; it serves as an eternal admonition against rejecting the *Hujjah* (divine proof) in any era, whether prophet or Imam. This interconnection between revelation, leadership, and human accountability remains central to Shia soteriology and ethical frameworks.
13.layer3:
In Surah Dukhaan 44:13, the Quran questions humanity’s neglect of divine guidance despite receiving a "clear Messenger"—a theme contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Makarem Shirazi contextualize as a timeless critique of willful ignorance. Modern commentaries, such as those by Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, emphasize that the verse challenges societies to confront their moral complacency, even amid accessible truth. Today, this resonates with what philosopher Abdolkarim Soroush calls "epistemic arrogance": the dismissal of spiritual or ethical truths in an age of scientific materialism, despite overwhelming evidence of humanity’s need for transcendent purpose.  

The verse’s rhetorical question—"How will there be for them a reminder?"—parallels modern crises where societies ignore clear warnings, from climate denial to systemic inequality. Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim notes that Imam Ali’s teachings in *Nahjul Balagha* frame such negligence as a failure to align intellect with conscience, urging proactive engagement with justice. Scientifically, this aligns with cognitive dissonance theory: humans often reject inconvenient truths, even when presented irrefutably—a dynamic seen in vaccine hesitancy or AI ethics debates.  

Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Alul Bayt World Assembly, highlight shared Abrahamic concerns about societal heedlessness. In multicultural contexts, the verse invites reflection on how communities uphold collective responsibility. For instance, climate activists like Greta Thunberg echo prophetic urgency, demanding accountability for ignored "reminders."  

Ultimately, this verse calls for humility before truth—a principle as vital in navigating AI governance or ecological collapse as in seventh-century Arabia. It challenges us to ask: When guidance is evident, what barriers—social, psychological, or ideological—keep us from heeding it? The answer, as Shia theology insists, lies in cultivating *taqwa* (mindful awareness) to transcend self-deception and act justly.
13.layer4:
The verse from Surah Ad-Dukhaan questions how those who rejected divine guidance could seek a "reminder" after rejecting the "clear Messenger" sent to them. In Shia tafsir, this verse carries profound implications about recognizing divine authority (Wilayah) and the necessity of submitting to the Prophet (PBUH) and his purified progeny (Ahlul Bayt). Imam Ali (AS) taught that the Messenger’s clarity lies not only in his message but in his connection to the eternal truth embodied by the Imams. A hadith from Imam Sadiq (AS) in *Tafsir al-Qummi* states: "The 'clear Messenger' is Muhammad (PBUH), and the 'reminder' is the Imam from us. When they turn from the Messenger, how can they find the reminder? For the Imam is the living reminder of Allah’s covenant."

This verse underscores the inseparable link between Prophethood (Nubuwwah) and Imamah. The Ahlul Bayt (AS) emphasize that true guidance is not merely hearing the message but embracing the divine light of Wilayah. Lady Fatimah (AS) declared in her famed sermon: "Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and our Wilayah the safeguard against division." Rejecting the Messenger’s authority while seeking spiritual awakening is a contradiction—the "reminder" they ignore is the very presence of the Imam, the manifest proof (Hujjah) of Allah.

Practically, this verse calls believers to internalize the reality that every moment of heedlessness is a rejection of the Imam’s living guidance. Spiritual development hinges on aligning one’s heart with the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, seeking their intercession (Tawassul), and upholding their rights. As Imam Zain al-Abidin (AS) supplicates in *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*: "O Allah, make me among those who remember through Your reminders and obey Your proofs." True remembrance is loyalty to the Imams—the inheritors of divine knowledge—whose footsteps lead to eternal proximity to Allah.

تبتابائی ، *المزان *میں ، میسنجر اور پیغام کے مابین اونٹولوجیکل تعلقات پر پھیلتا ہے۔ ان کا استدلال ہے کہ نبی کی موجودگی خود ہی ایک حتمی "یاد دہانی" تشکیل دیتی ہے ، جس کے نتیجے میں غیر منطقی ثبوت کے لئے کال کی جاتی ہے۔ اس طرح یہ آیت ان لوگوں کی مذمت بن جاتی ہے جو نبی کے معجزات اور اخلاقی کمال کے مشاہدہ کرنے کے باوجود انکار پر قائم رہتے ہیں۔ یہ ایک مؤقف ہے جس نے شیعہ کے نقادوں کو ان لوگوں کے نقادوں کا عکسبند کیا ہے جنہوں نے نبی کی موت کے بعد امام علی کی صحیح قیادت کو مسترد کردیا۔ مذہبی طور پر ، یہ * لوٹف * (خدائی فضل) کے اصول کی عکاسی کرتا ہے ، جس کے تحت خدا کفر کے لئے انسانی بہانے کو دور کرنے کے لئے غیر واضح رہنمائی فراہم کرتا ہے۔

فقہی طور پر ، آیت شیعہ قانونی نظریہ کا سنگ بنیاد ، الہی الہی مقرر کردہ حکام کی ذمہ داری کو تقویت بخشتی ہے۔ "واضح میسنجر" کو پہچاننے میں ناکامی محض تاریخی سرزنش سے ماورا ہے۔ یہ کسی بھی دور میں * ہجاہ * (خدائی ثبوت) کو مسترد کرنے کے خلاف ابدی نصیحت کا کام کرتا ہے ، چاہے وہ نبی ہوں یا امام۔ وحی ، قیادت ، اور انسانی احتساب کے مابین یہ باہمی ربط شیعہ سوٹریولوجی اور اخلاقی فریم ورک کا مرکزی مرکز ہے۔

13.layer5:
The verse’s rhetorical question—“How will there be for them a reminder [at that time]? And there had come to them a clear Messenger”—addresses the rejection of divine guidance by disbelievers despite receiving explicit revelation. Both Sunni and Shia exegetes broadly concur that the “clear Messenger” refers to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), whose mission provided an unequivocal warning to his contemporaries. Scholars across traditions, including Tabari and Tabatabai, contextualize this verse within narratives of divine chastisement, emphasizing that rejecting the Prophet after his message had been plainly delivered leaves no justification for seeking repentance during punishment.  

A key area of convergence lies in interpreting the “reminder” (*dhikra*) as the Quran itself or the broader concept of divine admonition. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi both stress that the verse underscores human accountability, noting that the disbelievers’ obstinacy rendered them spiritually heedless despite the clarity of the Prophet’s mission. Similarly, Qurtubi and Tusi highlight the Quran’s role as an enduring reminder, with Tusi adding that its teachings remain accessible to those who reflect.  

Divergences emerge in theological emphases. Shia commentaries, particularly in Al-Mizan and Tafsir al-Qummi, often extend the concept of “reminder” to include the Prophet’s progeny (*Ahl al-Bayt*) as inheritors of divine guidance. Tabatabai argues that the verse implicitly critiques those who ignored both the Messenger and his divinely appointed successors, reflecting the Shia doctrine of Imamah. Sunni exegetes like Razi and Tabari, while acknowledging the Quran’s preservation, focus on the Prophet’s singular role as the final messenger, aligning with Sunni theological frameworks that prioritize textual and communal transmission (*naql*) over hereditary authority.  

These differences stem from distinct historical developments in early Islam, particularly debates over leadership after the Prophet’s passing. While Sunni scholarship emphasizes communal adherence to the Quran and Sunnah, Shia thought integrates the Imams’ infallible guidance into the concept of divine remembrance. Both traditions, however, reinforce the centrality of heeding revelation and the moral consequences of its rejection, shaping devotional practices centered on Quranic reflection and prophetic emulation.

13.summary: This verse, as Allama Tabatabai notes in Al-Mizan, expands on the ontological relationship between the Messenger and the message. In Surah Ad-Dukhaan verse 13, Allah poses a profound rhetorical question: "How will there be for them a reminder [at that time]? And there had come to them a clear Messenger. " This verse addresses the disbelievers of Mecca who rejected Prophet Muhammad (SAW) despite his clear message. The term *adh-dhikra* (the reminder) refers to both the Quran’s guidance and the opportunity to repent, while *rasoolun mubeen* (clear Messenger) underscores the Prophet’s role as an unambiguous bearer of truth. Imam Ali (AS) taught that the Messenger’s clarity lies not only in his message but in his connection to the eternal truth embodied by the Imams. By internalising the "reminder" through daily reflection on divine teachings and embodying the Messenger’s clarity in our conduct, we avoid the heedlessness condemned in this verse.
13.layer2short: In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:13), the verse poses a profound rhetorical question: "How will there be for them a reminder [at that time]? And there had come to them a clear Messenger." Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, emphasize the theological implications of rejecting divine guidance after the advent of an unequivocal Messenger. The verse underscores the inexcusability of disbelief once truth has been manifestly delivered, a theme recurrent in Shia theology concerning the necessity of recognizing both prophetic and Imamic authority.

14.layer1:
This verse from Surah Ad-Dukhaan captures the painful rejection faced by Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) when conveying Allah’s message. After witnessing his profound teachings and moral example, the disbelievers of Quraysh turned away (*tawallaw*)—a term implying both physical and spiritual rejection—and resorted to slander. They dismissed him as *mu'allam* (one taught by human teachers) and *majnun* (mad or possessed), two accusations meant to undermine his prophethood. Historically, this reflects the Meccan elite’s refusal to accept divine revelation, fearing it threatened their social power and pagan traditions. Their insults reveal a pattern of discrediting truth-tellers through baseless claims, a tactic seen in earlier prophets’ struggles.

The term *mu'allam* suggests they accused the Prophet of secretly learning from others, denying the Qur’an’s miraculous nature. *Majnun* implies irrationality, attacking his credibility. In Shia tafsir, scholars like Tabatabai note that such slander exposes the arrogance of those who prioritize ego over truth. The Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali, emphasized that rejecting divine guidance often stems from attachment to worldly status, not intellectual doubt.

Today, this verse reminds Muslims to reflect on how they respond to truth. When faced with ethical or spiritual challenges, do we dismiss uncomfortable truths with modern equivalents of “madness” labels—mocking, oversimplifying, or attributing noble efforts to ulterior motives? It also calls believers to stand firm like the Prophet, trusting divine wisdom over popular opinion. In defending justice or promoting faith, expect resistance but respond with patience and clarity, as taught by the Ahlul Bayt. The verse ultimately reassures that truth prevails, and false accusations fade, just as Islam’s light outshone the Quraysh’s lies.
14.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah Ad-Dukhaan 14 by situating the verse within the broader Quranic narrative of prophetic rejection. The verse captures the Meccan polytheists’ dual accusation against Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his progeny): that his revelations were merely human teachings ("mu'allam") and that he was mentally unstable ("majnun"). Tabatabai emphasizes that such slander reflects a recurring pattern of disbelievers dismissing divine messengers through ad hominem attacks, seeking to negate the supernatural origin of revelation. He notes that the term "mu'allam" implies the Quraysh’s false assertion that the Prophet learned scripture from a hidden tutor—a trope Shia exegesis often links to their denial of *wahy* (divine inspiration) and the ontological uniqueness of prophethood.

Shaykh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualizes this verse within the theological framework of *ismah* (prophetic infallibility). The accusation of madness, he argues, exposes the disbelievers’ spiritual blindness to the coherence and wisdom of the Quran—a text whose linguistic and doctrinal perfection inherently refutes such baseless claims. Classical Shia commentators universally interpret these accusations as manifestations of *kufr* (disbelief) rooted in arrogance (*istikbar*), a refusal to submit to divine truth epitomized by the Ahl al-Bayt’s teachings. 

Theologically, this verse underscores the Shia understanding of divine knowledge (*'ilm ladunni*) as an unmediated gift from God to His chosen guides, contrasting sharply with the disbelievers’ materialist worldview. The rejection of Muhammad’s message prefigures the historical opposition faced by the Imams, who inherited and preserved this prophetic knowledge. As articulated in Shia hadith literature, such verses are often interpreted as affirming the necessity of divinely appointed leadership—a core tenet of Imamate doctrine. Thus, the verse transcends its historical context, serving as a perennial reminder of the struggle between divinely guided truth and human obstinacy.
14.layer3:
In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:14), the Qur’an captures a recurring theme in prophetic history: the dismissal of divine messengers through accusations of insanity or inauthenticity. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasser Makarem Shirazi, contextualize this verse as a reflection of humanity’s tendency to reject transformative truths that challenge entrenched power structures or cultural norms. He notes in his exegesis that the Meccan elite’s claim that Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was “taught” (implying human fabrication) or “mad” mirrors modern intellectual arrogance that reduces spiritual insight to pathology or conspiracy.  

From a psychosocial lens, scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this verse to cognitive dissonance theory: when confronted with moral or existential truths, societies often attack the bearer rather than engage the message. This dynamic manifests today in the vilification of activists, whistleblowers, or ethical leaders—from climate scientists labeled “alarmists” to reformers dismissed as “radicals.” The verse invites reflection on epistemic humility: how do we respond to ideas that disrupt our comfort?  

Interfaith parallels emerge in the Christian narrative of Jesus being called “possessed” (John 10:20) or the Buddha’s teachings initially rejected as “extremist.” Multicultural societies today face similar challenges in balancing free speech with respect for diverse truth-claims. Ayatollah Sayed Ahmad Alamolhoda, a contemporary Iranian scholar, emphasizes that the verse calls for *dialogue* over dismissal—a principle vital for navigating religious pluralism and ideological polarization.  

Modern neuroscience adds nuance: studies on “predictive coding” suggest the brain resists information contradicting its worldview. This biological tendency, when unchecked, becomes societal inertia against justice. The verse thus serves as a timeless warning: progress demands overcoming the instinct to pathologize difference, whether in prophets, pioneers, or marginalized voices.
14.layer4:
The verse exposes the spiritual blindness of those who rejected Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family), attributing his divinely inspired message to human teaching or madness. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Burhan* that such accusations stem from arrogance that veils hearts from recognizing divine truth: **"When souls are intoxicated with worldly attachments, they mock the light of guidance as madness."** This mirrors the eternal struggle between Haqq (Truth) and Batil (falsehood) – a theme central to the mission of the Ahlul Bayt.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) declared in her famed sermon: **"My father brought the gleaming light, yet they called him a liar. By Allah, their eyes were sealed by the dust of their own sins!"** Here, "taught" and "mad" symbolize humanity’s tendency to rationalize away truths that challenge their desires. The Imams teach that rejecting Wilayah (divine guardianship) manifests similarly in every age – dismissing the Imamah as irrational or impractical when it conflicts with ego-driven logic.

Imam Ali (peace be upon him) warns in *Nahj al-Balagha*: **"The Quran’s truths are buried under the arrogance of those who measure revelation by their intellects."** Practical guidance lies in cultivating submission (tasleem) to divine authority. Daily self-reflection (muhasaba) purifies the heart to recognize the Prophet’s true heirs. Reciting Ziyarat Ashura, engaging with the Duas of the Ahlul Bayt, and studying their teachings dismantle the ego’s false narratives.

Ultimately, this verse calls believers to embrace the "madness" of divine love over the "sanity" of worldly logic. As Imam Hussain (peace be upon him) demonstrated at Karbala, true wisdom lies in sacrificing all for Truth – a path illuminated only through loyalty to the purified Guides.

14.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 44:14, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on its historical context: the Meccan polytheists’ rejection of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and their baseless accusations against his prophethood. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) agree the verse critiques the Quraysh’s psychological denial mechanisms, dismissing divine revelation as either human-taught knowledge (“mu’allam”) or madness (“majnun”). Ibn Kathir and Al-Tabrisi both contextualise this within the broader Meccan opposition narrative, noting how such slander aimed to undermine the Quran’s divine origin.  

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Shia commentators like Al-Qummi and Tabatabai often highlight the epistemic blindness of rejecting divinely appointed guidance, framing the verse as part of a recurring theme where communities spurn prophets and their successors (Ahl al-Bayt). Al-Mizan links the “mu’allam” accusation to the broader Quranic defence of revelation’s transcendence beyond human instruction. Sunni scholars like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi focus more on the Prophet’s moral steadfastness, with Al-Razi’s Mafatih al-Ghayb analysing the rhetorical structure of the dual accusation (“taught” and “mad”) as logically contradictory, thereby exposing the opponents’ irrationality.  

Practically, Shia interpretations often connect such verses to the necessity of following infallible guidance (Imamate), while Sunni readings emphasise communal adherence to the Prophet’s authenticated Sunnah. These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Shia exegesis frequently integrates Imamology into Quranic hermeneutics, whereas Sunni tradition prioritises the Prophet’s historical experience and textual transmission. Both traditions, however, unite in deriving lessons about resisting false accusations against divine truth and upholding the Quran’s celestial origin.

15.layer1:
This verse from Surah Ad-Dukhaan addresses the recurring pattern of human response to divine mercy and warnings. When Allah says, *"Inna kashifu al-adhab qalilan innakum a'idun"*, He reveals a profound truth: temporary relief from suffering often leads people to revert to arrogance and rejection of truth rather than gratitude. Historically, this verse connects to the Quraysh’s persistent rejection of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). When severe drought struck Mecca as a warning, they begged him to pray for rain, promising to believe if relief came. Once the rain fell, they broke their pledge and returned to mocking Islam—exposing their insincerity.  

The key term *kashifu al-adhab* (removing the torment) highlights Allah’s mercy even in discipline, granting people time to reflect. However, *a'idun* (you will return) underscores humanity’s tendency to relapse into heedlessness when tests ease. Scholars like Allamah Tabatabai note in *Tafsir al-Mizan* that this verse critiques hollow, transactional faith—seeking Allah only in crisis, then abandoning Him when comfort returns.  

For modern Muslims, this serves as a timeless lesson. In times of ease after hardship—whether personal struggles, societal crises, or global challenges—we must guard against complacency. Relief is not a license to forget the Source of blessings but an invitation to deepen gratitude and commitment. The verse urges self-reflection: Do we turn to Allah only when desperate, then neglect Him once safe? Do communities revert to injustice after temporary reforms? True faith requires consistency beyond momentary fear. By internalizing this, believers cultivate *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) that endures through life’s ebbs and flows, aligning actions with principles rather than fluctuating circumstances.
15.layer2:
In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:15), the divine declaration *"Indeed, We will remove the torment for a little. Indeed, you [disbelievers] will return [to disbelief]"* encapsulates a profound theological dynamic central to Shia exegesis. Classical commentators such as Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* and Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* situate this verse within the narrative of temporary respite granted to disbelievers as both a test of their spiritual resolve and a manifestation of divine forbearance. The "removal of torment" is interpreted not as a permanent reprieve but as a strategic delay (*istidraj*) allowing humanity to exercise free will, thereby exposing their intrinsic spiritual orientation. Tabrisi notes that such respite serves to distinguish the steadfast believer from the recalcitrant rejecter, aligning with the Quranic principle that divine mercy coexists with justice.

Tabatabai expands this analysis by linking the verse to the Shia emphasis on *tawhid al-af’al* (the oneness of divine acts), wherein even temporary relief from suffering is a calculated divine act to facilitate existential accountability. The phrase "you will return" (*innakum a'idun*) is understood as an ontological inevitability for those whose hearts are sealed by persistent arrogance (*istikbar*), reflecting the Shia doctrine that spiritual regression stems from willful rejection of truth (*juhud*) rather than mere ignorance. This aligns with the teachings of Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who emphasized that divine signs are perpetually accessible, but their rejection entrenches disbelief.

The verse also resonates with Shia eschatology, wherein temporary worldly relief contrasts with the finality of hereafter judgment. Jurisprudentially, this underscores the necessity of *amr bil-ma’ruf* (enjoining good) as a communal duty to prevent spiritual relapse. Thus, the verse transcends its historical context, offering a timeless lesson on the interplay between divine patience, human agency, and the unyielding reality of ultimate reckoning.
15.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:15 is often interpreted as a profound reflection on humanity’s cyclical tendency to lapse into heedlessness after moments of divine respite. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that the verse underscores Allah’s mercy in granting temporary relief from suffering—not as an endpoint, but as an opportunity for spiritual awakening. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this dynamic to today’s global crises, noting how societies often revert to exploitative systems after brief periods of reform, mirroring the “return to disbelief” described in the verse.  

Philosophically, the verse resonates with the concept of *temporary solutions* in social justice movements. For instance, climate policies that address symptoms (e.g., carbon offsets) but fail to dismantle extractive capitalism reflect the “removal of torment for a little” without systemic change. Neuroscientific insights into habit formation—how humans default to ingrained behaviors under stress—add a layer of empirical understanding to the Quranic warning.  

Interfaith parallels emerge here: Buddhist teachings on *samsara* (cyclical suffering) and Christian notions of “backsliding” echo the verse’s theme. In multicultural contexts, this verse invites reflection on collective responsibility—whether in addressing pandemics, inequality, or war, temporary relief risks complacency unless paired with sustained ethical commitment.  

Scholar Fatemeh Fakhraie ties this to modern activism, arguing that social progress requires vigilance against the “return” to oppressive norms. The verse thus becomes a call to transcend short-termism, urging alignment with the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on enduring justice (e.g., Imam Ali’s emphasis on *qist*). In an era of fleeting digital attention and political amnesia, this ancient warning feels urgently contemporary.
15.layer4:
In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:15), Allah declares a temporary lifting of punishment for those persisting in disbelief, only to warn that they will inevitably return to their destructive ways. The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) teach that this verse transcends its historical context, offering profound insights into the spiritual cycles of trial and human responsibility.  

Imam Ali (عليه السلام) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "Allah tests His servants with ease as He tests them with hardship, lest they become complacent in blessings or despairing in affliction." This verse exemplifies Allah’s mercy granting respite, not as approval, but as an opportunity for self-reform. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (عليه السلام) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that "returning [to disbelief]" signifies humanity’s tendency to abandon gratitude when trials subside, mistaking temporary relief for permanent security.  

The Ahlul Bayt emphasize that true spiritual progress requires recognizing divine tests in both hardship *and* ease. Lady Fatimah (عليها السلام) taught: "The comfort of this world is a trial more hidden than the edge of a hair" (*Bihar al-Anwar*), warning that prosperity often breeds forgetfulness of Allah. This verse thus becomes a mirror for self-reflection: Do we "return" to negligence when blessings increase, or deepen our connection to the Divine?  

Key Shia concepts like *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) offer the antidote. Imam Ali (عليه السلام) asserts: "Hold firmly to the rope of the Imams, for they are your safeguard from returning to the pit of ignorance." By anchoring oneself in the guidance of the Infallibles, one transforms temporary respites into stepping stones toward eternal proximity to Allah.  

1. In times of ease, increase acts of gratitude (shukr) and charity.  
2. Reflect daily: "Am I using this blessing to draw closer to Allah or distract myself from Him?"  
3. Seek protection through devotion to the Ahlul Bayt, whose teachings illuminate the straight path amidst life’s fluctuating trials.  

As Imam al-Baqir (عليه السلام) taught: "The believer is like a reed – shaken by winds but never uprooted." This verse calls us to build unshakable roots in divine truth.

جدید مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ ایک لازوال سبق کا کام کرتا ہے۔ مشکلات کے بعد آسانی کے وقت - چاہے ذاتی جدوجہد ، معاشرتی بحرانوں ، یا عالمی چیلنجوں کو - ہمیں خود کو خوشنودی سے بچانا چاہئے۔ ریلیف نعمتوں کے منبع کو فراموش کرنے کا لائسنس نہیں ہے بلکہ شکرگزار اور عزم کو گہرا کرنے کی دعوت ہے۔ آیت خود کی عکاسی پر زور دیتی ہے: کیا ہم صرف اللہ کی طرف رجوع کرتے ہیں جب مایوس ہو ، پھر اسے ایک بار سلامتی کو نظرانداز کریں؟ کیا عارضی اصلاحات کے بعد کمیونٹیز ناانصافی کی طرف لوٹ گئیں؟ حقیقی ایمان کو لمحہ بہ لمحہ خوف سے بالاتر مستقل مزاجی کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔ اس کو اندرونی بناتے ہوئے ، مومنین * تواکول * (اللہ پر بھروسہ) کاشت کرتے ہیں جو زندگی کے ایبس اور بہاؤ کے ذریعے برداشت کرتے ہیں ، اور اتار چڑھاو کے بجائے اصولوں کے ساتھ اعمال کی صف بندی کرتے ہیں۔

سور Surah اڈ-دوخان (44:15) میں ، الہی اعلامیہ * "واقعی ، ہم تھوڑا سا عذاب ختم کردیں گے۔ بے شک ، آپ [کافر] [کفر] واپس آجائیں گے" * * شیعہ کی ایک بڑی تعداد میں ایک گہرا مذہبی متحرک مرکزی مرکزیت کا احاطہ کرتا ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین جیسے شیخ تبریسی * ماجما البیان * اور * المزان * میں علامہ تبتابائی * اس آیت کو عارضی مہلت کی داستان میں پیش کرتے ہیں جو کافروں کو ان کے روحانی عزم کا امتحان اور الہی رواداری کا مظہر دونوں کے طور پر دیا گیا ہے۔ "عذاب کو ختم کرنے" کی ترجمانی مستقل بازیافت کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ اسٹریٹجک تاخیر (*istidraj*) کے طور پر کی جاتی ہے جس سے انسانیت کو آزادانہ خواہش کا استعمال کرنے کی اجازت دی جاتی ہے ، اور اس طرح ان کے اندرونی روحانی رجحان کو بے نقاب کیا جاتا ہے۔ تبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ اس طرح کی مہلت مستحکم مومن کو بازیافت کرنے والے مسترد کرنے والے سے ممتاز کرنے کا کام کرتی ہے ، اور قرآنی اصول کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتی ہے جو الہی رحمت انصاف کے ساتھ مل کر رہتی ہے۔

تبتابائی نے اس تجزیے کو * توحید الافال * (الہی اعمال کی وحدانیت) پر شیعہ پر زور دینے سے آیت کو جوڑ کر اس تجزیے کو بڑھایا ہے ، جس میں یہاں تک کہ مصائب سے عارضی طور پر ریلیف بھی موجود ہے۔ "آپ واپس آجائیں گے" (*انومکم آیدن*) کے فقرے کو ان لوگوں کے لئے ایک آنٹولوجیکل ناگزیر سمجھا جاتا ہے جن کے دل مستقل تکبر (*استیبر*) کے ذریعہ مہر لگائے جاتے ہیں ، جو شیعہ کے نظریہ کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں کہ روحانی رجعت محض جہالت کے بجائے سچائی کے جان بوجھ کر رد jection ہ (*جوہڈ*) سے پیدا ہوتا ہے۔ یہ امام جعفر السادق کی تعلیمات کے مطابق ہے ، جس نے اس بات پر زور دیا کہ خدائی علامتیں مستقل طور پر قابل رسائی ہیں ، لیکن ان کے مسترد ہونے سے کفر میں شامل ہوتا ہے۔

یہ آیت شیعہ ایسکیٹولوجی سے بھی گونجتی ہے ، جس میں عارضی دنیاوی امدادی اس کے فیصلے کی حتمی شکل سے متصادم ہے۔ فقہی طور پر ، اس سے روحانی طور پر دوبارہ ہونے سے بچنے کے لئے فرقہ وارانہ فرض کے طور پر * امر بل-ماؤرف * (اچھ .ا کام) کی ضرورت کی نشاندہی ہوتی ہے۔ اس طرح ، آیت اپنے تاریخی سیاق و سباق سے بالاتر ہے ، جو خدائی صبر ، انسانی ایجنسی ، اور حتمی حساب کتاب کی ناقابل برداشت حقیقت کے مابین باہمی مداخلت پر ایک لازوال سبق پیش کرتی ہے۔

عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ اڈ-ڈوخان 44:15 کو اکثر الہی مہلت کے لمحات کے بعد انسانیت کے چکرمک رجحان پر گہری عکاسی کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی نے اپنے *طافسیر نمونیہ *میں اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ آیت اللہ کی رحمت کو تکلیف سے عارضی طور پر راحت دینے میں اس کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے۔ ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی جیسے جدید اسکالرز اس متحرک کو آج کے عالمی بحرانوں سے مربوط کرتے ہیں ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ کس طرح معاشرے اصلاح کے مختصر ادوار کے بعد اکثر استحصال کرنے والے نظام کی طرف لوٹتے ہیں ، اور آیت میں بیان کردہ "کفر میں واپسی" کی عکس بندی کرتے ہیں۔  

فلسفیانہ طور پر ، آیت سماجی انصاف کی تحریکوں میں * عارضی حل * کے تصور سے گونجتی ہے۔ مثال کے طور پر ، آب و ہوا کی پالیسیاں جو علامات (جیسے ، کاربن آفسیٹس) کی نشاندہی کرتی ہیں لیکن نکالنے میں ناکام سرمایہ داری کو ختم کرنے میں ناکام رہتی ہیں۔ عادت کی تشکیل کے بارے میں اعصابی بصیرت - کس طرح انسانوں کو تناؤ کے تحت جکڑے ہوئے طرز عمل سے طے شدہ ہے - قرآنی انتباہ کے لئے تجرباتی تفہیم کی ایک پرت کو شامل کرتا ہے۔  

انٹرفیتھ کے متوازی یہاں سامنے آتے ہیں: * سمسارا * (چکرانی تکلیف) پر بدھ مت کی تعلیمات اور "بیک سلائیڈنگ" کے عیسائی خیالات آیت کے موضوع کی بازگشت کرتے ہیں۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، یہ آیت اجتماعی ذمہ داری پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے - چاہے وبائی امراض ، عدم مساوات ، یا جنگ ، عارضی امداد کے خطرات سے نمٹنے کے لئے جب تک کہ اخلاقی عزم کے ساتھ جوڑا نہ بنائے۔  

اسکالر فاطیمہ فخری نے اس کا تعلق جدید سرگرمی سے کیا ہے ، اور یہ استدلال کیا ہے کہ معاشرتی پیشرفت کو جابرانہ اصولوں کی "واپسی" کے خلاف چوکسی کی ضرورت ہے۔ اس طرح یہ آیت قلیل مدتی کو عبور کرنے کا مطالبہ بن جاتی ہے ، جس میں پائیدار انصاف (جیسے ، امام علی کا *قِت *پر زور دینے) کے بارے میں اہل بیت کی تعلیمات کے ساتھ صف بندی پر زور دیا جاتا ہے۔ ڈیجیٹل توجہ اور سیاسی امونیا کے دور دراز کے دور میں ، یہ قدیم انتباہ فوری طور پر ہم عصر محسوس ہوتا ہے۔

امام علی (عالیہ السلام) میں *ناہج البالاگھا *میں کہا گیا ہے: "اللہ اپنے خادموں کو آسانی کے ساتھ جانچتا ہے جب وہ ان کی مشکلات کی جانچ کرتا ہے ، ایسا نہ ہو کہ وہ مصیبت میں برکت یا مایوسی میں مطمعن ہوجائیں۔" یہ آیت اللہ کی رحمت کی مثال کے طور پر ، منظوری کے طور پر نہیں ، بلکہ خود اصلاح کے موقع کے طور پر مہلت دینے کی مثال دیتی ہے۔ امام جعفر السادق (علیہ السلام) نے * طافسیر القومی * میں وضاحت کی ہے کہ "[کفر کی طرف] لوٹنا" انسانیت کے شکرگزار کو ترک کرنے کے رجحان کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے جب آزمائشیں ختم ہوجاتی ہیں ، مستقل سلامتی کے لئے عارضی طور پر امداد کی غلطی کرتے ہیں۔

جیسا کہ امام البقیر (علیہ السلام) نے سکھایا: "مومن ایک سرکنڈے کی طرح ہے-ہواؤں سے لرز اٹھا لیکن کبھی جڑ سے اکھاڑ نہیں ہوا۔" یہ آیت ہمیں الہی سچائی میں غیر متزلزل جڑیں بنانے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔
15.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:15, both Shia and Sunni scholars converge on the verse’s core theme: Allah’s temporary respite from punishment as a test of human accountability, coupled with humanity’s tendency to revert to disbelief. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) both contextualise this verse within the narrative of Pharaoh’s defiance, emphasising that divine mercy is conditional and cyclical. Similarly, Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) highlight the universality of this pattern, noting that respite (raf‘ al-‘adhab) serves as an opportunity for repentance, though often squandered by those entrenched in arrogance.

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir anchor the verse in specific historical contexts, such as the temporary relief granted to the Quraysh during the Year of Sorrow, interpreting “returning to disbelief” as a literal relapse. Shia commentators, particularly Al-Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, extend the principle beyond history, framing it as a recurring trial tied to humanity’s rejection of divine guidance, implicitly linking this to the rejection of the Ahlul Bayt’s leadership. Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir* further underscores this typological reading, associating the “disbelievers” with those who opposed the Imams’ authority.

Theological foundations differ subtly: Sunni interpretations often prioritise literal application (zahir) and historical precedent, while Shia exegesis leans toward symbolic (batin) meanings tied to walayah (allegiance to the Imams). This distinction influences religious practice, with Sunni traditions emphasising gratitude during periods of ease, and Shia teachings stressing steadfastness amid trials as a reflection of loyalty to divine guardianship. Historically, these differences stem from varying epistemological frameworks—Sunni reliance on communal consensus (ijma‘) and Shia prioritisation of the Imams’ hermeneutical authority—yet both traditions uphold the verse’s ethical imperative: divine mercy demands sincere, sustained submission.

مذہبی زور سے تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ ابن کتھیر کی طرح سنی کی منظوریوں نے مخصوص تاریخی سیاق و سباق میں آیت کو لنگر انداز کیا ، جیسے غم کے سال کے دوران قریش کو دی جانے والی عارضی ریلیف ، "کفر کی طرف لوٹنے" کو لفظی دوبارہ سے تعبیر کرنے کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے۔ شیعہ مبصرین ، خاص طور پر *المزان *میں التباطابائی ، تاریخ سے بالاتر اس اصول کو بڑھا دیتے ہیں ، اور اسے انسانیت کے الہی رہنمائی کے مسترد ہونے سے منسلک ایک بار بار چلنے والی آزمائش کے طور پر تیار کرتے ہیں ، اور اسے واضح طور پر اہل بیت کی قیادت کو مسترد کرنے سے جوڑتے ہیں۔ القومی کا * طافسیر * اس ٹائپولوجیکل پڑھنے کی مزید نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، اور "کافروں" کو ان لوگوں کے ساتھ جوڑتا ہے جنہوں نے اماموں کے اختیار کی مخالفت کی ہے۔

مذہبی بنیادیں بالکل مختلف ہیں: سنی کی تشریحات اکثر لفظی اطلاق (ظہیر) اور تاریخی نظیر کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ استثنیٰ علامتی (بیٹن) کے معانی کی طرف جھک جاتا ہے جو والیاہ (اماموں کی بیعت) سے منسلک ہوتا ہے۔ یہ امتیاز مذہبی رواج کو متاثر کرتا ہے ، جس میں سنی روایات آسانی کے ادوار کے دوران شکرگزار پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اور شیعہ تعلیمات الہی سرپرستی کے ساتھ وفاداری کی عکاسی کے طور پر آزمائشوں کے درمیان ثابت قدمی پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات مختلف علمی فریم ورک سے مختلف ہیں - فرقہ وارانہ اتفاق رائے پر سنی انحصار (آئی جے ایم اے ‘) اور شیعہ اماموں کی’ ہرمینیٹیکل اتھارٹی کی ترجیح - دونوں روایات کو آیت کی اخلاقی لازمی طور پر برقرار رکھتے ہیں: خدائی رحمت مخلص ، مستقل پیش کش کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔
15.summary: According to classical exegesis in Tafsir al-Mizan, *Majma al-Bayan* and Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* situate this verse within the narrative of temporary respite granted to disbelievers as both a test of their spiritual resolve and a manifestation of divine forbearance. This verse from Surah Ad-Dukhaan addresses the recurring pattern of human response to divine mercy and warnings. When Allah says, *"Inna kashifu al-adhab qalilan innakum a'idun"*, He reveals a profound truth: temporary relief from suffering often leads people to revert to arrogance and rejection of truth rather than gratitude. Historically, this verse connects to the Quraysh’s persistent rejection of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). Imam Ali (عليه السلام) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "Allah tests His servants with ease as He tests them with hardship, lest they become complacent in blessings or despairing in affliction. By internalizing this, believers cultivate *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) that endures through life’s ebbs and flows, aligning actions with principles rather than fluctuating circumstances.
15.layer2short: In Surah Ad-Dukhaan (44:15), the divine declaration *"Indeed, We will remove the torment for a little. Indeed, you [disbelievers] will return [to disbelief]"* encapsulates a profound theological dynamic central to Shia exegesis. Classical commentators such as Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* and Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* situate this verse within the narrative of temporary respite granted to disbelievers as both a test of their spiritual resolve and a manifestation of divine forbearance. The "removal of torment" is interpreted not as a permanent reprieve but as a strategic delay (*istidraj*) allowing humanity to exercise free will, thereby exposing their intrinsic spiritual orientation. Tabrisi notes that such respite serves to distinguish the steadfast believer from the recalcitrant rejecter, aligning with the Quranic principle that divine mercy coexists with justice.
15.layer2short_urdu: سور Surah اڈ-دوخان (44:15) میں ، الہی اعلامیہ * "واقعی ، ہم تھوڑا سا عذاب ختم کردیں گے۔ بے شک ، آپ [کافر] [کفر] واپس آجائیں گے" * * شیعہ کی ایک بڑی تعداد میں ایک گہرا مذہبی متحرک مرکزی مرکزیت کا احاطہ کرتا ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین جیسے شیخ تبریسی * ماجما البیان * اور * المزان * میں علامہ تبتابائی * اس آیت کو عارضی مہلت کی داستان میں پیش کرتے ہیں جو کافروں کو ان کے روحانی عزم کا امتحان اور الہی رواداری کا مظہر دونوں کے طور پر دیا گیا ہے۔ "عذاب کو ختم کرنے" کی ترجمانی مستقل بازیافت کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ اسٹریٹجک تاخیر (*istidraj*) کے طور پر کی جاتی ہے جس سے انسانیت کو آزادانہ خواہش کا استعمال کرنے کی اجازت دی جاتی ہے ، اور اس طرح ان کے اندرونی روحانی رجحان کو بے نقاب کیا جاتا ہے۔ تبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ اس طرح کی مہلت مستحکم مومن کو بازیافت کرنے والے مسترد کرنے والے سے ممتاز کرنے کا کام کرتی ہے ، اور قرآنی اصول کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتی ہے جو الہی رحمت انصاف کے ساتھ مل کر رہتی ہے۔

16.layer1:
In Surah Ad-Dukhaan, verse 16, Allah declares: *"Yawma nabtishu al-batshata al-kubra inna muntaqimun"* — "The Day We will strike with the greatest assault, indeed, We will take retribution." This powerful verse refers to a decisive moment of divine justice, when Allah will deliver ultimate retribution against oppressors and tyrants. The term *al-batshata al-kubra* (the greatest assault) signifies an unparalleled act of divine punishment, surpassing all worldly consequences. The word *batsha* itself implies a sudden, overwhelming strike, reflecting the absolute power and inevitability of Allah’s justice. *Muntaqimun* (those who take retribution) emphasises that Allah alone holds the authority to exact perfect justice, balancing oppression with recompense.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as that by Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, links this verse to both historical and eschatological contexts. Historically, it warned the Quraysh’s elite who persecuted early Muslims in Mecca, reminding them of the fate of earlier unjust nations like Pharaoh’s people. Eschatologically, it points to the Day of Judgment, when all moral accounts will be settled. For Shia Muslims, this verse also resonates with the suffering of the Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Hussain (AS) at Karbala, reinforcing the belief that divine justice ultimately prevails, even if delayed.

Today, this verse reassures Muslims facing injustice or persecution that Allah’s justice is certain, urging patience and trust in His wisdom. It also serves as a moral warning: oppression and arrogance invite divine accountability. Practically, it inspires believers to align their actions with justice, support the marginalised, and remain steadfast in adversity, knowing that true recompense lies with Allah. In a world rife with inequality, this verse is a timeless call to faith in divine balance and a reminder that worldly power is fleeting before the *batshata al-kubra* of the Hereafter.
16.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis, Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:16 is understood as a profound articulation of divine justice (*‘adl*) and eschatological reckoning. The "greatest assault" (*al-batshah al-kubra*) is interpreted through both cosmic and historical lenses. Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* emphasizes its dual resonance: it refers to the cataclysmic events of the Day of Judgment, when divine wrath manifests conclusively, and simultaneously alludes to historical moments of divine retribution against oppressors of truth, such as the annihilation of Pharaoh’s forces or the Quraysh’s moral corruption. This duality reflects the Shia theological principle that divine justice operates across temporal and metaphysical realms.

Shia commentators like Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* contextualize the verse within the paradigm of *intiqam* (retribution), underscoring its alignment with the Quranic theme of ultimate accountability. The verse’s assertion "Indeed, We will take retribution" is tied to the theological axiom that God’s vengeance is not arbitrary but a measured response to systemic injustice (*zulm*), particularly against the oppressed (*mustad'afeen*). In Shia thought, this extends to the persecution of the Ahl al-Bayt, with some narratives linking the "great assault" to the eschatological restoration of justice through Imam al-Mahdi (aj), who will avenge the blood of Imam al-Husayn (as) and his followers.

The verse also reinforces the Shia doctrinal emphasis on the interplay between divine decree and human moral agency. Retribution here is not merely punitive but pedagogical, serving to affirm the consequences of rejecting divine guidance. Jurisprudentially, this underscores the necessity of enjoining justice and resisting oppression (*amr bil-ma'ruf*), as neglect of these duties invites collective divine accountability. Thus, the verse synthesizes eschatological hope with ethical imperative, central to Shia soteriology.
16.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars interpret Surah Ad-Dukhaan 44:16 as a profound reminder of divine justice intertwined with cosmic and ethical order. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis *Tafsir Nemuneh*, frames the "great assault" (*al-batsha al-kubra*) as both a historical reality (e.g., Pharaoh’s downfall) and an eschatological warning, emphasizing that divine retribution manifests through natural laws and human moral choices. This duality bridges classical theology with modern systems thinking: the verse’s cosmic scale resonates with scientific understandings of ecological collapse or pandemics as consequences of human exploitation, aligning with scholars like Dr. Seyyed Hossein Nasr, who links environmental crises to spiritual neglect.

Modern thinkers, such as philosopher Dr. Mohammad Legenhausen, contextualize the verse within social justice struggles, framing "retribution" as divine support for oppressed communities resisting systemic inequities—a theme central to Shia narratives of Imam Hussain’s stand against tyranny. The verse’s urgency speaks to contemporary issues like climate injustice, where marginalized nations bear disproportionate harm from industrial excess, echoing Imam Ali’s admonitions against greed and imbalance.

Interfaith dialogues find common ground here: the Qur’anic concept of *intiqam* (retribution) parallels Buddhist karma and Judeo-Christian divine justice, underscoring shared ethical imperatives. Multiculturally, it challenges societies to address structural violence—from economic apartheid to war—as manifestations of collective moral failure. Scholar Reza Shah-Kazemi notes that such verses invite introspection, urging transformative accountability rather than passive fear. In an era of AI and existential risks, the "great assault" warns against hubristic technologies divorced from ethical frameworks, urging harmony with divine and natural laws.
16.layer4:
The verse from Surah Ad-Dukhaan speaks of a momentous Divine intervention where ultimate justice manifests. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this "great assault" transcends mere physical punishment; it is the culmination of cosmic justice against those who rejected truth and oppressed the sacred reality of Tawhid and Wilayah. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: "The *Batshat al-Kubra* refers to the Day of Qiyamah, but every era has its own 'assault' against falsehood. The greatest assault is the unveiling of truth through the Qa'im [Imam Mahdi], when the world will be purified by the light of justice."  

This verse reminds believers that Divine retribution is inseparable from the rejection of *Imamah*, the spiritual axis of creation. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) said: "One who dies without recognizing the Imam of his time dies the death of ignorance." To be spared from the "assault," one must anchor their soul in loyalty (*Tawalla*) to the Ahlul Bayt and dissociation (*Tabarra*) from their enemies. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) declared in her famed sermon: "Allah’s retribution strikes those who usurp the rights of the chosen ones, for they sever the rope of Wilayah."  

Practically, this verse calls for daily self-accounting: Do our actions align with the Imams' teachings? Are we nurturing love for the Ahlul Bayt in our hearts? Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that "the true believer sees with the light of Allah," meaning spiritual vigilance against inner corruption is essential. Reciting Dua al-Ahd, seeking forgiveness through Ziyarat Ashura, and embodying justice in small acts are shields against the soul’s vulnerability on that Day. The "great assault" is both a warning and a mercy—a call to awaken before the final dawn of truth arrives with the Imam’s reappearance.

سورہ اڈ-ڈوخان میں ، آیت 16 ، اللہ نے اعلان کیا: * "یاواما نبٹیشو البٹشتا الکبرا انا منکیمون" *-"جس دن ہم سب سے بڑے حملے کے ساتھ حملہ کریں گے ، واقعی ، ہم بدلہ لیں گے۔" اس طاقتور آیت سے مراد خدائی انصاف کے فیصلہ کن لمحے سے مراد ہے ، جب اللہ ظلم و ستم اور ظالموں کے خلاف حتمی بدلہ پہنچائے گا۔ اصطلاح * البٹشتا الکوبرا * (سب سے بڑا حملہ) الہی سزا کے بے مثال فعل کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جس سے تمام دنیاوی نتائج کو پیچھے چھوڑ دیا گیا ہے۔ لفظ * باتشا * خود اچانک ، زبردست ہڑتال کا مطلب ہے ، جو اللہ کے انصاف کی مطلق طاقت اور ناگزیر ہونے کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ * منکیمون* (جو لوگ بدلہ لیتے ہیں) اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ صرف اللہ ہی کامل انصاف کا اختیار حاصل کرتا ہے ، اور اس کی تکمیل کے ساتھ ظلم کو متوازن کرتا ہے۔

کلاسیکی شیعہ طافسیر ، جیسے کہ الامہ تبتابائی کے ذریعہ *المزان *میں ، اس آیت کو تاریخی اور اسکیٹولوجیکل سیاق و سباق دونوں سے جوڑتا ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، اس نے قریش کے اشرافیہ کو متنبہ کیا جنہوں نے مکہ میں ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو ظلم کیا ، اور انہیں فرعون کے لوگوں جیسی سابقہ ناجائز قوموں کی قسمت کی یاد دلاتے ہوئے کہا۔ اسکاٹولوجیکل طور پر ، یہ فیصلے کے دن کی طرف اشارہ کرتا ہے ، جب تمام اخلاقی اکاؤنٹس طے ہوجائیں گے۔ شیعہ مسلمانوں کے ل this ، یہ آیت اہل بیت کے مصائب سے بھی گونجتی ہے ، خاص طور پر امام حسین (ع) کربلا میں ، اس عقیدے کو تقویت بخشتی ہے کہ الہی انصاف بالآخر غالب ہے ، چاہے تاخیر سے بھی۔

آج ، یہ آیت مسلمانوں کو ناانصافی یا ظلم و ستم کا سامنا کرنے والے مسلمانوں کو یقین دلاتا ہے کہ اللہ کا انصاف یقینی ہے ، اور اس کی دانشمندی پر صبر اور اعتماد پر زور دیتا ہے۔ یہ اخلاقی انتباہ کے طور پر بھی کام کرتا ہے: ظلم اور تکبر الہی احتساب کو مدعو کرتے ہیں۔ عملی طور پر ، یہ مومنین کو انصاف کے ساتھ اپنے اعمال کی سیدھ میں لانے ، پسماندہ کی حمایت کرنے اور مشکلات میں ثابت قدم رہنے کی ترغیب دیتا ہے ، یہ جانتے ہوئے کہ حقیقی بدلہ اللہ کے ساتھ ہے۔ عدم مساوات کے ساتھ ایک دنیا میں رائف میں ، یہ آیت خدائی توازن پر اعتماد کی ایک لازوال کال ہے اور یہ یاد دہانی ہے کہ دنیاوی طاقت اس کے بعد * باتشتا الکوبرا * کے سامنے بحری جہاز ہے۔

کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ میں ، سورہ اڈ-ڈوخان 44:16 کو خدائی انصاف (*‘ADL*) اور اسکیٹولوجیکل حساب کتاب کے گہرے بیان کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ "سب سے بڑا حملہ" (*البٹشاہ الکوبرا*) کائناتی اور تاریخی دونوں لینسوں کے ذریعہ تشریح کی جاتی ہے۔ الامہ تبتابائی * المزان * نے اپنی دوہری گونج پر زور دیا ہے: اس سے مراد یومیہ فیصلے کے تباہ کن واقعات سے مراد ہے ، جب الہی غص .ہ حتمی طور پر ظاہر ہوتا ہے ، اور بیک وقت حقیقت کے جابرانہ بدعنوانی کے تاریخی لمحات کے بارے میں بات کرتا ہے ، جیسے فرعون کی فورسز یا کیوریس کی فنا کی طرح۔ یہ دوہری شیعہ مذہبی اصول کی عکاسی کرتی ہے جو الہی انصاف دنیاوی اور استعاریاتی دائروں میں چلتا ہے۔

شیعہ مبصرین جیسے شیخ تبریسی * مجاہ البیان * * انٹیکم * (بدلہ) کے نمونہ کے اندر آیت کو سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں ، اور حتمی احتساب کے قرآنی موضوع کے ساتھ اس کی سیدھ کو واضح کرتے ہیں۔ آیت کا یہ دعویٰ "واقعتا ، ہم بدلہ لیں گے" مذہبی محور سے منسلک ہے کہ خدا کا انتقام صوابدیدی نہیں ہے بلکہ نظامی ناانصافی (*زولم*) کا ماپا ردعمل ہے ، خاص طور پر مظلوم (*مستند'افین*) کے خلاف۔ شیعہ کے خیال میں ، یہ اہل البائٹ کے ظلم و ستم تک پھیلا ہوا ہے ، جس میں کچھ بیانیے "عظیم حملے" کو امام المحدی (اے جے) کے ذریعہ انصاف کی بحالی سے جوڑتے ہیں ، جو امام الحسین (ع) اور اس کے پیروکاروں کے خون کا بدلہ لیں گے۔

آیت الہی الہی فرمان اور انسانی اخلاقی ایجنسی کے مابین باہمی مداخلت پر شیعہ نظریاتی زور کو بھی تقویت دیتی ہے۔ یہاں بدلہ محض تعزیر ہی نہیں بلکہ تدریسی ہے ، جو خدائی رہنمائی کو مسترد کرنے کے نتائج کی تصدیق کرنے کے لئے کام کرتا ہے۔ فقہی طور پر ، اس سے انصاف کو مسترد کرنے اور جبر کے خلاف مزاحمت کرنے کی ضرورت کی نشاندہی ہوتی ہے (*امر بل-ماؤرف*) ، کیونکہ ان فرائض کو نظرانداز کرنے سے اجتماعی الہی احتساب کی دعوت دی جاتی ہے۔ اس طرح ، آیت اخلاقی لازمی کے ساتھ ایسکیٹولوجیکل امید کی ترکیب کرتی ہے ، جو شیعہ سوٹریولوجی کا مرکزی مرکز ہے۔
